title: 104_hr4110
content: The "Children Health Insurance Act of 1996" is cited in Section 1. It amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a chapter on Health Insurance Availability for Children, which includes provisions for an excise tax on failure to provide access to coverage. The tax imposed on group health plans and insurers for failing to meet coverage requirements is 25% of premiums received. Self-insured plans are treated the same as premiums for this tax. The tax imposed on insurers offering individual health insurance coverage is 25% of the total premiums paid for the plan year in which the failure occurs. There are limitations on the tax amount, such as no tax if the failure was not discovered with reasonable diligence or if the failure is corrected within 30 days. The tax imposed on insurers for failures in individual health insurance coverage can be waived if the failure is corrected within 30 days and was due to reasonable cause, not willful neglect. The tax does not apply to governmental or church plans. The tax imposed on insurers for failures in individual health insurance coverage can be waived if corrected within 30 days and was not willful neglect. This tax does not apply to governmental or church plans. "SEC. 9902. REQUIREMENT OF ACCESS TO COVERAGE." Group health plans must offer qualifying coverage for qualifying young dependents of participants or beneficiaries. The offer must be made when a person first becomes a qualifying young dependent and at least annually thereafter. Insurers in the individual market must offer qualifying coverage for individuals under 21 years old who are US citizens or nationals. Qualifying coverage includes health care benefits without limitations based on pre-existing conditions. Qualifying coverage includes Medicare benefits under parts A and B of title XVIII of the Social Security Act, well child care benefits, and coverage without limitations based on pre-existing conditions or waiting periods. Well child care benefits include payment for newborn and well-baby care, routine office visits, immunizations, laboratory tests, and preventive dental care without deductibles or coinsurance. The Secretary, in consultation with the American Academy of Pediatrics, establishes a periodicity schedule for these services. The Secretary, in consultation with the American Academy of Pediatrics, establishes a periodicity schedule for preventive dental care services for qualifying young dependents under 21 years of age in the United States. Managed care is permitted for accessing these benefits without limitations on providers. The Secretary, in consultation with the American Academy of Pediatrics, establishes a periodicity schedule for preventive dental care services for qualifying young dependents under 21 years of age in the United States. Managed care is permitted for accessing these benefits without limitations on providers. SEC. 9903 defines key terms. In this chapter, the term 'group health plan' is defined as per section 5000(b)(1), excluding plans with medical benefits limited to coverage in paragraph (2)(B). 'Health insurance coverage' refers to medical care benefits under various policies or contracts, excluding coverage for accident or credit-only policies. The term 'health insurance coverage' excludes certain types of coverage such as accident, credit-only, vision, disability income, long-term care, nursing home care, dental, on-site medical clinics, employee assistance programs, Medicare supplemental health insurance, supplemental coverage under a group health plan, coverage issued as a supplement to liability insurance, and liability insurance including general and automobile liability insurance. The term 'health insurance coverage' excludes accident, credit-only, vision, disability income, long-term care, nursing home care, dental, on-site medical clinics, employee assistance programs, Medicare supplemental health insurance, and supplemental coverage under a group health plan. It includes liability insurance supplements, workers' compensation, automobile medical-payment insurance, specified disease coverage, hospital indemnity insurance, short-term limited duration insurance, and other comparable coverage as specified in regulations. The term 'insurer' refers to an insurance company, service, or organization licensed to conduct insurance business in a State. This includes health maintenance organizations regulated under State law for solvency similar to federally qualified ones. The term 'insurer' encompasses insurance companies, services, or organizations licensed to operate in a State under State insurance regulations. The 'individual market' refers to health insurance coverage offered to individuals, excluding employer-based or group plans. The terms 'beneficiary' and 'participant' have meanings as defined in the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 defines terms related to beneficiaries and participants. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include new items. Subtitle L. Health Insurance Availability for Children. The requirement of section 9902 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 shall take effect on January 1, 1998, and apply to coverage offered on or after that date. A refundable tax credit for the purchase of health coverage for children is introduced in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The tax credit allows individuals to claim 80% of qualified health premiums paid in the taxable year. The credit is applied against tax liability at a rate of $0.50 for each $1 of tax liability, with tax liability defined as the excess of the tax imposed for the year and social security taxes over the credit allowed under section 32. The taxpayer can claim a credit for social security taxes paid in the taxable year, which includes taxes on received amounts and self-employment income. The credit is applied against tax liability at a rate of $0.50 for each $1 of tax liability. The taxpayer can claim a credit for social security taxes paid in the taxable year, which includes taxes on received amounts and self-employment income. The credit is applied against tax liability at a rate of $0.50 for each $1 of tax liability. The term 'social security taxes' excludes taxes eligible for a special refund under section 6413(c) and includes amounts paid under agreements related to foreign affiliates. The definition of 'qualified health premium' refers to the amount paid for health coverage. The section defines terms related to health coverage, including 'qualified health premium' for young dependents. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections. The section includes provisions for purchasing health coverage for children and addressing overpayments of tax, with amendments applying to taxable years starting after December 31, 1997.
